page.title: 08CHIDDINGLYE WOOD
page.content: This lies in the valley on the east side of the B.2028 road south of {Chiddinglye Farm.}The trees are mainly deciduous with{rhododendrons}planted in the last century. The west side falls steeply from the road with much of the sandstone exposed with trees, mainly beech, growing well out of the rock. The{Cob Brook,}a tributary of the{Ouse,}flows through the wood and there is a{hammer pond}which powered a furnace when the iron industry flourished in the area. There are many sandstone outcrops including the rock {Great Upon Little.}On the SE border is a rocky promontory between two valleys, the site of a large{Romano {British camp}protected on three sides by a horseshoe of rocks, its apex Great Upon Little. Both wood and camp are privately owned.
